javax.lang.posit

Class Posit

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Number
      • javax.lang.posit.Posit
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<Posit>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PositStringImpl

    public abstract class Posit
extends java.lang.Number
implements java.lang.Comparable<Posit>
    An implementation of Posit numbers for Java. Deines base class methods.

    In addition, this class provides several methods for converting a Posit to a String and a String to a Posit, as well as other constants and methods useful when dealing with a Posits.

    More information from John Gustafson: Beating Floating Point

    Implementation classes of Posit decide which primitive type to use to support size and dynamic range:

    • byte (8 bit) - most compact, lowest range,
    • short (16 bit),
    • int (32 bit),
    • long (64 bit) - less compact, higher range,
    • String - arbitrary length, least compact, arbitrary range.

    APIs for this class fall into these groups:

    • Constructors - methods for creating Posits,
    • Number interface - methods for converting to/from Java Number types,
    • Conversion - methods for converting to/from other types such as String,
    • Math - value testing, arithmetic operations,
    • Object methods - Java hash, equals, toString, compare,
    • Posit domain - methods such as regime, useed, exponent, size, implementation
    Author:
    Dan Becker
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • doubleValueGustafson

        public abstract double doubleValueGustafson()
        Returns value of this Posit as a double after a primitive conversion.

        This method uses the Gustafson method of calculating fractions.

        Returns:
        the Posit value represented by this object converted to type double

      • parse

        public void parse(java.lang.String s)
           throws java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Sets internal representation from the given String.
        Parameters:
        s - a string of the format ("0","1")*. If the string has whitespace, it is trimmed. If the string starts with "0b" it is trimmed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NumberFormatException - if the string does not contain a parsable binary number.

      • isInfinite

        public boolean isInfinite()
        Returns true if this Posit value is infinitely large in magnitude, false otherwise.

        Regardless of bit size, infinity is bit[0] == 1, all others zero.

        Returns false for uninitialized or bitSize 0.

        Returns:
        true if the value represented by this object is positive infinity or negative infinity; false otherwise.

      • isZero

        public boolean isZero()
        Returns true if this Posit value is zero, false otherwise.

        Regardless of bit size, zero is all bits zero.

        Returns false for uninitialized or bitSize 0.

        Returns:
        true if the value represented by this object is zero; false otherwise.

                          Posit p2)

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        0 if p1 == p2, <0 if p2<p1, >0 if p2>p1

      • getImplementation

        public abstract java.lang.Class<?> getImplementation()
        Returns the native implementation class of this Posit. For example: String, Byte, Short, Integer, Long, etc..
        Returns:
        Class of this implementation

      • getBitSize

        public abstract int getBitSize()
        Returns the number of bits in this Posit.
        Returns:
        number of bits in this Posit

      • isPositive

        public abstract boolean isPositive()
        Returns whether the sign bit is set or not.

        If the bit size is 0, returns false.

        Note that Zero is considered positive, Infinity is not.

        Returns:
        if this Posit is positive (has the sign bit set)

      • isExact

        public abstract boolean isExact()
        Returns whether the Posit is an exact number or not. Numbers such as 0, ∞, 1, 2, 4, 1/2, 1/4 are exact. Other Posits are approximations lying in the interval between two exacts

        Posits are exact when the last bit is 0.

        Returns:
        if this Posit is exact (has the last bit unset)

      • getRegime

        public abstract java.lang.String getRegime()
        Returns the regime bits of this Posit as a String of "0" and "1".

        If the bit size is less than 2, returns empty String.

        First char of Posit is sign bit.

        Regime is first char until terminated by end of string or until opposite char.

        Examples "0", "1", "00", "01", "10", "11"

        Returns:
        a string of "0" and "1" representing the regime

      • getRegimeK

        public abstract int getRegimeK()
        Returns the regime value K.

        Let m be the number of identical bits starting the regime; if the bits are 0, then k = −m; if the bits are 1, then k = m − 1.

        Examples (regime = K): 0000=-4, 0001=-3,001x=-2,01xx=-1,10xx=110x=1,1110=2,1111=3

        Returns:
        a value representing the K of the regime bits

      • getMaxExponentSize

        public abstract byte getMaxExponentSize()
        Returns the maximum exponent size or em in this Posit.

        Normally any part of the Posit after the sign and the regime comprise the exponent and the fraction. Both may be absent. However, when present, the maximum number of exponent bits is given by this value.

        Es or "exponent size" is the actual length of the exponent string in a posit instance. For example, in a 5 bit posit with em of 2, there are posit instances with es = 0, 1, and 2.

        Returns:
        maximum number of exponent bits in this Posit

      • setMaxExponentSize

        public abstract void setMaxExponentSize(byte maxExponentSize)
        Sets the maximum exponent size or em in this Posit.
        Parameters:
        maxExponentSize - a value of 0 to 255 for maximum exponent size.

      • getExponent

        public abstract java.lang.String getExponent()
        Returns the exponent bits of this Posit as a String of "0" and "1".

        If the sign and regime bits fill the bit size, the exponent may be empty string. If the exponent and fraction are not zero length, es or "exponent size" will be the length of this String.

        Returns:
        a string of "0" and "1" representing the exponent

      • getFraction

        public abstract java.lang.String getFraction()
        Returns the exponent bits of this Posit as a String of "0" and "1".

        If the sign and regime bits fill the bit size, the exponent may be empty string. If the exponent and fraction are not zero length, es or "exponent size" will be the length of this String.

        Returns:
        a string of "0" and "1" representing the exponent

      • getFractionMultiplier

        public abstract double getFractionMultiplier()
        Returns the fraction to scale the Posit value.

        In general, fractional bits of a posit are used to scale the value. If a fraction is given as f0..fn fraction bits, the multiplier is 1.0 + val( fn ) / 2^n

        For example, a one bit fraction (n=1) will have multipliers fm(0,1)=1.0,1.5. A two bit fraction (n=2) will have multipliers of fm(00,01,10,11)=1.0,1.25,1.5,1.75

        Returns:
        the fraction scaling multiplier

      • getUseed

        public abstract java.math.BigInteger getUseed()
        Returns the useed of this Posit Useed is 2 ** 2 ** run length of regime.

        Given es as the size of the exponent, useed = 2^2^es, and scale = useed^k Examples (es = useed): 0=2,1=2^2=4,2=4^2=16,3=16^2=256,4=256^2=65536

        Returns:
        a BigInteger representing the Useed.
